thread.title: St John rewards 'heroes' for courage, skill and exceptional judgement in emergencies - ABC News (Australian Broadcasting Corporation)
thread.title_full: St John rewards 'heroes' for courage, skill and exceptional judgement in emergencies - ABC News (Australian Broadcasting Corporation)

author: Eliza Laschon
title: St John rewards 'heroes' for courage, skill and exceptional judgement in emergencies - ABC News (Australian Broadcasting Corporation)
text:
"We've just had a bad smash on Mundijong Road," were the words of paramedic Sharron Price during the triple-0 call she made after the ambulance she was driving was involved in a horrific head-on crash. 
Her colleague Wesley Ackerman was trapped upside down, with critical injuries in the passenger seat. 
"I can hear him moaning," she told the operator. 
"We seriously need at least two ambulances, please ... they can see that he's still alive, but it's really badly crushed." 
The crash happened in the early hours of October 10 last year as the ambulance was travelling along Mundijong Road in Oldbury, south of Perth. 
The emergency response was swift, and those who are usually called to help others, arrived at the crash site to try to save one of their own. 
St John Ambulance Area Manager Brendan Saich was one of the first on the scene. 
"It wasn't until I turned the corner of that road and saw an ambulance up on its roof that I realised the reality of that job," Mr Saich said. 
The emergency services team freed Mr Ackerman from the wreckage, secured his airway and gave him lifesaving blood. 
"With the adrenaline you go to scene and do the best you can no matter what the job," Mr Saich said. 
"It was after the event ... it hit home how lucky he was." 
The 33-year-old father of three regained consciousness weeks later in hospital. 
"With all the drugs they gave me, it gave me amnesia so the last thing I remember is going to bed ... the night before and then waking up a couple of weeks later," Mr Ackerman said. 
"It takes my breath away just to think of how these guys all worked on me just to keep me alive." 
The team of eight are among 17 West Australians recognised by St John Ambulance WA at a ceremony on Wednesday for their "exceptional judgement and skill to deliver care.. in a medical emergency". 
"They are my heroes ... I can't thank them enough. I am alive because of them," Mr Ackerman said about his colleagues. 
Mr Wesley is working hard in his rehabilitation to get back to the job. 
"It is my passion. It is what I have done all my life. I help people, that is what I do."
